choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery would most likely compromise the blood supply to which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e., right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

 

 

  • The common hepatic artery typically divides into the hepatic proper artery and the gastroduodenal artery.
  • The hepatic proper artery, in turn, gives rise to the right gastric artery (which supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach) and continues as the left and right hepatic arteries for the liver.
  • The gastroduodenal artery gives off the right gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Thus, if the common hepatic artery is ligated, blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries would be impaired.

 

Branches of hepatic artery (Mnemonic – Girls R So Cute)

 

  • Gastroduodenal artery > divides into right gastroepiploic and superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
  • Right gastric artery
  • Supra duodenal artery (inconstant)
  • Cystic artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right gastric and left gastric artery: While the right gastric artery does arise from the hepatic proper artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery), the left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the left gastric artery's blood supply.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery). The short gastric arteries, however, typically arise from the splenic artery, another direct branch of the celiac trunk. Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the blood supply of the short gastric vessels.

 

Option D. Right gastric and short gastric vessels: As mentioned earlier, the right gastric artery arises from the hepatic proper artery. The short gastric arteries arise from the splenic artery. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would only affect the right gastric artery's blood supply, not the short gastric vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery affects the blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries due to their derivation from the hepatic proper and gastroduodenal arteries respectively.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle, marked A in the given coronal CT image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and abdominal pain. There is a history of 1 blood transfusion in the past. On examination, he had icterus and mild splenomegaly. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sickle cell disease

 

The given scenario with increased HbA2, HbF, and S spikes on electrophoresis suggests sickle cell disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The fundamental molecular lesion: The basic genetic defect in HbS is a single point mutation in one amino acid out of 146 in the hemoglobin molecule—there is a substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6-residue position of the beta -globin, producing HbS.  This causes sickle-shaped red blood cells to be produced due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

 

Infection, dehydration, and acidosis are all risk factors for sickling.

 

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

 

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Vaso-occlusive phenomenon due to obstruction to capillary blood flow by sickled red cells upon deoxygenation or dehydration:
    • Microinfarcts affecting particularly the abdomen, chest, back and joints and are the cause of recurrent painful crises in SS.
    • Microinfarcts involving most commonly the spleen (splenic sequestration, auto splenectomy), bone marrow (pains), bones (aseptic necrosis, osteomyelitis), lungs.
    • (Pulmonary infections), kidneys (renal cortical necrosis), CNS (stroke), retina (damage) and skin (ulcers), and result in anatomic and functional damage to these organs.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Hemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta thalassemia: Typically presents with severe anemia and requires frequent blood transfusions. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2 and HbF but does not show a significant S spike.

 

Option B. HbC disease: Characterized by the presence of hemoglobin C, which does not cause the severe symptoms seen in sickle cell disease. Electrophoresis would show HbC rather than HbS.

 

Option D. Acute coronary disease: Not relevant to the presentation described, as it does not explain the recurrent infections, abdominal pain, icterus, and splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is characterized by the presence of HbS, leading to recurrent infections, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, and splenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and an S spike. The genetic mutation involves the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

questions.text: Which of the following cardioselective beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisoprolol

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been clinically proven to reduce mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF). It works by decreasing the heart rate, reducing myocardial oxygen demand, and limiting the harmful effects of sympathetic nervous system activation in heart failure. Along with metoprolol and carvedilol, bisoprolol is one of the few beta-blockers approved for use in CHF due to its demonstrated benefits in reducing mortality and improving patient outcomes.

 

Remember - Drugs that decrease mortality are primarily those that inhibit the renin-angiotensin pathway, including beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, ARBs (angiotensin II receptor blockers), and angiotensin receptor blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is not typically used in the management of CHF due to its lack of cardioselectivity. It has not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with CHF.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking properties. While it is useful in the management of hypertensive emergencies, it is not used for chronic management of CHF and has not been shown to decrease mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Pindolol: Pindolol is another non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA). It is not suitable for CHF management and does not have evidence supporting a mortality benefit in heart failure patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A hair shaft with arthroconidia is seen in the image below. Identify the fungi associated with it? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microsporum

 

The image shows a hair shaft containing arthroconidia, which are fungal spores that develop within or on the surface of the hair. The key points to consider are:

 

  • Endothrix and Ectothrix: Endothrix refers to fungal infections where the spores (arthroconidia) are found inside the hair shaft, while ectothrix refers to infections where spores are found on the outside of the hair shaft.
  • Microsporum: Although typically associated with ectothrix infections, in this scenario, it is the most appropriate answer given that the other options are less likely to produce this specific pattern.

 

Despite Microsporum generally being linked to ectothrix infections, it remains the best answer in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichosporon: Incorrect because it is associated with white piedra and does not form arthroconidia within the hair shaft.

 

Option C. Candida: Incorrect because Candida does not cause infections within the hair shaft; it is primarily involved in mucosal and cutaneous infections.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton: Incorrect because this fungus does not infect hair; it is more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microsporum can be associated with fungal infections of the hair shaft, particularly in cases where arthroconidia are observed. Even though it is more commonly linked with ectothrix infections, it is the best option among the given choices for this scenario

questions.text: All of the following are true about Kleine-Levin syndrome (KLS), EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anorexia

 

Explanation:


Kleine-Levin Syndrome (KLS), sometimes referred to as “Sleeping Beauty Syndrome,” is a rare sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of:

  • Hypersomnia (sleeping up to 18–20 hours a day),
  • Hyperphagia (excessive eating),
  • Hypersexuality, and
  • Behavioral disinhibition.

 

These episodes typically last days to weeks, and in between episodes, individuals return to baseline functioning. KLS most often begins in male adolescents, usually between the ages of 10 -21years. KLS is marked by hyperphagia, not reduced appetite (Anorexia). The presence of voracious eating during episodes is a defining characteristic that helps differentiate it from other conditions with excessive sleepiness.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Sleeping Beauty Syndrome: This is a well-known nickname for KLS, reflecting the extended sleep durations during episodes.
  • Option C. Hypersomnia: This is a core diagnostic feature. Patients often sleep nearly continuously for days, only waking to eat or use the bathroom.
  • Option D. Hypersexuality: Frequently observed in KLS. It includes increased libido, inappropriate sexual behavior, or disinhibition during episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kleine-Levin Syndrome is defined by episodic hypersomnia, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality, with complete resolution between episodes.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive vision loss. Imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasm. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

 

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior choroidal artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the hippocampus, lateral geniculate body, posterior limb of the internal capsule, and the choroid plexus of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: It doesn't have a direct relationship with the optic chiasma, so an aneurysm here is less likely to cause vision disturbances related to chiasmal compression.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It is one of the three major paired arteries that supply the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies a significant portion of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The MCA is located laterally and doesn't directly overlie the optic chiasma. Thus, an aneurysm of the MCA typically would not impinge upon the optic chiasma.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): It is one of the major paired arteries that supplies the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The ACA runs superiorly to the optic chiasma, similar to the anterior communicating artery. However, the anterior communicating artery, given its position and course, is more commonly associated with aneurysms that affect the optic chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and is a part of the Circle of Willis, a circulatory anastomosis that supplies the brain.

 

Relation to Optic Chiasma: The anterior communicating artery runs superiorly to the optic chiasma. An aneurysm of this artery can impinge upon or compress the optic chiasma leading to visual disturbances, especially a particular kind of vision loss called bitemporal hemianopsia.

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

 

Explanation:

 

Progesterone only pills (POPs), also known as mini pills, act through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but they do not kill sperms in the cervical canal.

 

Incorrect. Progesterone only pills do not have a spermicidal effect. They do not kill sperm; instead, they work by altering the cervical mucus and preventing ovulation.

 

The mechanisms of action include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thickening the cervical mucus: This makes it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an egg.

 

Option B. Preventing ovulation: Although not as consistently as combined oral contraceptives, POPs can inhibit ovulation in some women.

 

Option D. Inhibiting penetration of sperm: By thickening the cervical mucus and affecting the endometrial lining, POPs inhibit the sperm’s ability to penetrate and fertilize an egg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone only pills prevent pregnancy by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and preventing sperm penetration, but they do not kill sperm in the cervical canal.

 

Ref: Page no 323, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. Then Bladder cancer cases were identified from both the groups in the current time. What type of study is being performed? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Retrospective cohort study

 

The study given here is a retrospective cohort study.

 

A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before commencing the investigations and study.

 

The given question tells that the workers in the industry were divided into two groups, first are those who are directly exposed and second are clerical staff who are not directly exposed to the suspected carcinogen.

 

The incidence of bladder cancer among these two groups is studied going backward tracking their records. Therefore, it’s a retrospective cohort study.

 

A simple comparison between these studies and an example is shown below:
 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prospective cohort study: Involves following a group over a time span till the development of outcome.

 

Option C. Case-control study: A case-control study involves comparing groups with a specific outcome (cases) with a rather healthy group (controls) and assessing their exposure history. In this case, workers are divided into groups based on their exposure status and the development of bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Intervention and response: Is not a type of epidemiological study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A retrospective cohort study involves examining historical data to investigate the relationship between exposure and outcomes. In this scenario, it is used to study the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer among workers over a 20-year period.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities. A provisional diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following cells are affected in multiple sclerosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oligodendrocytes

 

Explanation

 

Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.

 

In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microglia. are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.

 

Option C. Astrocytes. also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.

 

Option D. Ependymal cells. are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In multiple sclerosis, the primary pathological change occurs in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelinating neurons in the CNS. This leads to widespread neurological impairment due to the loss of myelin, affecting the efficiency of nerve signal transmission.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not result in water hardness? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Calcium carbonate

 

Hardness of water is caused by the presence of dissolved minerals, particularly calcium and magnesium ions. These minerals can come from various sources, such as natural deposits in soil and rocks, or from industrial and domestic activities.

 

There are two types of hardness of water:

 

Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium.

 

Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’
  • Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3)
  • 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water
  • Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate)
  • Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates
  • Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates
  • Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pitting of nails

 

The given scenario suggests alopecia areata in which geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of nail is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

Alopecia areata:

 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Autoimmune disease that causes non scaring patches of hair loss.
  • It is a T cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata.
  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease if it advances quickly, sparing white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called going white overnight.

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nail changes are common in alopecia areata, with nail pitting being the most frequent finding.
  • Nail pitting appears as small depressions on the nail surface.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.28-33

questions.text: What is the prevalence of a disease with an incidence of a disease of 4 cases per 1000 individuals in the population and an average duration of 2 years? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 8/1000

 

Prevalence represents the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time. It can be calculated using the relationship between incidence (the rate of new cases) and the average duration of the disease.

 

Given that the incidence of the disease is 4 per 1000 of the population, and the average duration of the disease is 2 years, we can calculate the prevalence as follows:

 

Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 or 0.8%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence can be calculated using the formula:

 

Prevalence = Incidence x Duration.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute bacterial prostatitis, including fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain. A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. E. coli

 

Escherichia coli, commonly known as E. coli, is a gram-negative bacillus and is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It's also a very common cause of urinary tract infections in general.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal gut flora. They are an infrequent cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

 

Option B. Proteus: Proteus species are gram-negative bacilli. They can cause a variety of infections, including urinary tract infections and, less commonly, prostatitis. A characteristic of Proteus infections is the production of urease, which splits urea into ammonia and leads to an alkaline urine that can cause struvite stone formation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus Agalactiae: Also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus. While it's a leading cause of neonatal infections, it's an infrequent cause of urinary tract infections in adults and an even rarer cause of prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the majority of cases and is frequently found in urinary tract infections.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child brought to the OPD with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks, and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik's spot is present. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Measles/Rubeola

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: The rash of rubella is similar in distribution to that of measles (rubeola) but it is less intensely red and confluent. Forchheimer spots (Red spots over palate) may be present.

 

 

Option C. Varicella: Varicella presents with rash which appears 24-48 hrs after prodromal symptoms, then rapidly to face & trunk. There are papules, vesicles & crusted vesicles, Centripetal distribution with greatest on trunk.

 

 

Option D. Mumps: Mumps presents with Painful enlargement of salivary gland, ear ache, jaw tenderness while chewing, dryness of mouth.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koplik spots and a characteristic rash that begins on the forehead behind the ears and spreads to the torso and extremities are pathognomonic for measles.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Extravasation into venous system
﻿﻿﻿Bilateral cornual block

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

 

The given HSG (hysterosalpingogram) film shows bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes, suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx. Hydrosalpinx is typically caused by the end result of repeated mild endo-salpingitis (inflammation of the fallopian tubes) by pyogenic organisms of low virulence but highly irritant.

 

The organisms involved include:

 

  • Staphylococcus
  • E. coli
  • Gonococcus
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

During the initial infection, the fimbriae become edematous and in-drawn with the serous surface, adhering together to produce closure of the abdominal ostium. The uterine ostium gets closed by congestion. This results in the secretion being pent up, causing the tube to distend. The distension is marked more in the ampullary region than in the more rigid isthmus. As the mesosalpinx is fixed, the resultant distension makes the tube curled and look 'retort'-shaped. The wall is smooth and shiny, containing clear fluid inside, which is usually sterile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extravasation into venous system: This would show contrast leaking into the venous system and not confined to the Fallopian tubes.

 

Option C. Normal HSG: A normal HSG would show patent Fallopian tubes without distension or blockage.

 

Option D. Bilateral cornual block: This would show blockage at the cornua (the point where the Fallopian tubes enter the uterine cavity) without the dilated, fluid-filled appearance seen in hydrosalpinx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrosalpinx is characterized by bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes filled with clear fluid, often due to repeated mild infections causing obstruction and distension.

 

Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PDA

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASD: ASD is the common congenital heart disease in down syndrome

 

Option B. VSD: VSD is the common congenital heart disease in infant of diabetic mother

 

Option D. PS: PS (pulmonary stenosis) is the common congenital heart disease in noonan and Alagille syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), followed by Pulmonary Stenosis (PS).

choices.text: D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with seizures. His past history is significant for an episode of fever with rash at 1 year of age which resolved spontaneously. What is the most helpful investigation to diagnose his condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgG measles in CSF

 

This patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), also known as Dawson disease, which is caused by infection with the measles virus. The CSF anti-measles antibodies - IgG antibodies will be elevated and hence, it is the most helpful investigation to diagnose this condition.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis: Mesial temporal lobe sclerosis is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy, not SSPE. It involves scarring in the temporal lobe but is not typically seen in SSPE.

 

Option C. IgM measles in CSF: IgM antibodies indicate a recent infection. In SSPE, the infection occurred years earlier, so IgG antibodies, not IgM, would be elevated in the CSF.

 

Option D. D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF: D C1Q4 antibodies are not relevant to the diagnosis of SSPE. These antibodies are associated with complement component 1q deficiency, which is linked to autoimmune conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), elevated CSF anti-measles IgG antibodies are key for diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the most common causative organism for verruca vulgaris? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Human papillomavirus-2

 

  • The hands, fingers, and knees of young children are the areas that are most frequently affected with common warts.
  • Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by human papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2) but is also related to types 1, 4, 27, and 57.

 

Below image depicts Verruca vulgaris:

 

 

Common warts typically have no symptoms. They appear as firm papules with a rough horny surface and exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed.

 

Treatment:

 

Topical – Salicylic acid, formalin, caustics etc.

 

Other:

 

  • Laser
  • Cryotherapy
  • Surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human papillomavirus-3 (HPV-3): While HPV-3 is a strain of the virus that can cause warts, it is not the predominant strain for verruca vulgaris.

 

Option B. Human papillomavirus-7 (HPV-7):

  • HPV-7 is associated with butcher's warts, which are common among meat handlers.
  • This strain is not the primary one responsible for the verruca vulgaris seen in the general population.

 

Option D. Human papillomavirus-1 (HPV-1): HPV-1 is mainly responsible for plantar warts, which appear on the soles of the feet as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • It is not the primary strain for verruca vulgaris on the hands and fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human papillomavirus-2 is the most common cause of verruca vulgaris (common warts), which is important for understanding the etiology and guiding treatment options for these lesions.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 25, Page no 25.43, 25.47, 25.48, 25.52

Andrew's Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology - 11th Edition Chapter 19, Page no 401

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

 

The above image is suggestive of a Cirsoid aneurysm.

 

  1. Definition: Cirsoid aneurysms, also known as arteriovenous fistulas or arteriovenous malformations, are abnormal connections between arteries and veins without the usual intervening capillaries.
  2. Common locations: They most commonly occur in the scalp and face, although they can occur in other locations in the body.
  3. Causes: They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired, often as a result of trauma.
  4. Symptoms: Cirsoid aneurysms often present as a pulsatile mass, sometimes accompanied by a bruit (a sound heard over an artery due to turbulent blood flow). They can cause cosmetic concerns, headaches, and in severe cases, bleeding.
  5. Diagnosis: They can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Angiography can provide a detailed view of the blood vessels.
  6. Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision, embolization (blocking off the abnormal vessels), or a combination of both. The choice of treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the patient's overall health status.
  7. Complications: If left untreated, they can result in complications such as bleeding, ulceration, and, rarely, heart failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Location: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that can affect multiple systems, including the skin and nerves.
  • Symptoms: Symptoms vary but can include skin tumors (neurofibromas), café-au-lait spots, and neurological problems

 

 

Option B. Liposarcoma:

 

  • Location: Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically arises in fat cells in various parts of the body, including the limbs and abdomen.
  • Causes: The exact cause is often unknown, but some genetic factors may contribute. Symptoms: Symptoms may include a painless lump, swelling, or pain in the affected area.

 

Option D. Varicocele:

 

  • Location: Varicoceles are dilated veins in the scrotum, specifically in the spermatic cord. Causes: Varicoceles often develop due to faulty valves in the testicular veins, which allow blood to pool in the scrotum.
  • Symptoms: They may cause a dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, especially after prolonged standing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on this image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

The image shows a chest X-ray with dextrocardia, a condition where the heart is positioned on the right side of the chest. This is a key feature of situs inversus, which is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome.

 

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by a triad of clinical features: recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. The presence of situs inversus, as indicated by dextrocardia on the X-ray, is a distinguishing feature that confirms the diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, characterized by thick, sticky mucus that can clog the airways and lead to infections. It does not typically present with situs inversus or dextrocardia.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Young syndrome also involves recurrent sinusitis and bronchiectasis, similar to Kartagener syndrome. However, it is distinguished by infertility due to azoospermia rather than situs inversus. The absence of dextrocardia or situs inversus on imaging excludes Young syndrome as the correct answer.

 

Option D. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal inflammation leading to crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal block, and enlarged nasal cavities. It does not involve bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, or situs inversus, making it unrelated to the features seen in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Kartagener syndrome is identified by the presence of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (including dextrocardia), which is clearly visible in the chest X-ray provided.

choices.text: X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets
Vitamin D dependent rickets type I
Vitamin D dependent rickets type II

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with developmental delay, recurrent chest infections and worsening bony pain. His serum PTH was normal. Calcium was normal and phosphate was low. There is no response to Vitamin D. The probable diagnosis is:(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets

 

  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder characterized by low phosphate levels in the blood due to impaired phosphate reabsorption by the kidneys. This condition can lead to bone deformities, bony pain, and growth delays. Normal PTH levels are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Nutritional rickets:

  • Nutritional rickets is typically caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In this case, the boy has normal serum PTH, which suggests that his body is not compensating for a Vitamin D deficiency. Additionally, his phosphate levels are low despite Vitamin D supplementation, which is not characteristic of nutritional rickets.

 

Option C: Vitamin D dependent rickets type I:

  • This condition is caused by a genetic mutation that impairs the conversion of Vitamin D to its active form. It usually presents with low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which is not in line with the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Option D: Vitamin D dependent rickets type II:

  • Vitamin D dependent rickets type II is another genetic disorder that affects the body's response to Vitamin D. It can lead to low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which do not match the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder that results in low phosphate levels and can present with bony pain, developmental delay, and recurrent infections. It is distinct from other forms of rickets due to its genetic basis and the characteristic low phosphate levels in the absence of Vitamin D response.

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/

choices.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following is the most definitive finding? (NEET PG 2021 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

 

Explanation:

 

Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • It presents with several distinct clinical features.

 

Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Short stature: Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom.
  • Primary amenorrhea: Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).
  • Shield-like chest: Broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • Webbed neck: Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck.
  • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Cardiac defects: Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common.
  • Renal anomalies: Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • Other features: Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.

 

Ultrasound Findings:

 

  • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).

 

Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.

 

Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Leave the IUCD in situ

questions.text: A 26-year-old conceives on the IUCD. Wants to continue pregnancy. Next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remove the IUCD gently

 

The Ans. is Remove the IUCD gently. When a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUCD should be removed if possible. Leaving the IUCD in situ is associated with risks such as preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and potential fetal anomalies. While removing the IUCD does carry a slightly increased risk of miscarriage, the overall benefits of removal outweigh the risks of leaving it in place. Removal should be done carefully, with appropriate counseling provided to the patient about the potential risks involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leave the IUCD in situ: Leaving the IUCD in place is not recommended as it can lead to complications like preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and other pregnancy complications. Therefore, it should be removed if the patient wishes to continue the pregnancy.

 

Option C. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): MTP is not appropriate in this scenario because the patient wishes to continue with the pregnancy. The focus should be on managing the pregnancy safely with the IUCD removed.

 

Option D. Progesterone support: Progesterone support is not indicated in this case as it does not address the main issue, which is the presence of the IUCD and its associated risks if left in place during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a pregnancy occurs with an IUCD in place and the patient wishes to continue, the IUCD should be removed gently to minimize risks associated with leaving it in situ.

questions.text: During evaluation of PUO, a patient's chest X-ray is as seen below. What is your diagnosis?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Miliary tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The given chest X-ray depicts miliary tuberculosis.

 

Miliary tuberculosis:

 

  • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT.
  • Hematogenous spread.

 

Miliary pattern D/D:   

 

  • Healed varicella
  • TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome
  • Hemosiderosis
  • Silicosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: Typically presents with bilateral opacities, predominantly in the perihilar regions, and may show Kerley B lines, none of which are visible in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Necrobiotic nodules: Commonly associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, presenting as larger, well-defined nodules, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Tuberculoma: Typically appears as a solitary, well-defined round lesion, often with a calcified center, not the diffuse pattern observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.

questions.text: Which of these is an indication for giving adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after resection and MRND? (An image of the flap reconstruction was shown).  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extranodal extension

 

Extranodal extension (ENE) refers to the spread of cancer beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding tissues. This feature has recently been added as a significant factor in the staging and management of head and neck cancers, including oral malignancies. ENE is associated with a poorer prognosis due to its aggressive nature and higher likelihood of recurrence. Therefore, it is a major criterion for adjuvant radiotherapy following surgery and MRND (modified radical neck dissection), as radiotherapy can help reduce the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple LN metastases: While having multiple involved lymph nodes is a sign of advanced disease, it alone does not necessarily mandate adjuvant radiotherapy unless combined with other factors, such as large nodal size (>3 cm) or other minor criteria.

Option C. T3 tumor: T3 tumors are generally considered advanced due to their size and extent. However, adjuvant radiotherapy is more strongly indicated when other adverse pathological features, such as ENE or involved surgical margins, are present.

 

Option D. Close margin (1.5-2 mm): Close surgical margins indicate that the tumor was resected near the boundary of normal tissue, increasing the risk of residual disease. However, a close margin alone is not as critical as an involved margin (<1 mm) and typically requires radiotherapy only if combined with other adverse features.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Extranodal extension is a key indication for adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after surgical resection and MRND due to its significant impact on prognosis and risk of recurrence.

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

 

  • More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement:
    • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Labor Care Guide (LCG), active labor begins at more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The older definition of active labor was at 4 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) now defines active labor as beginning at more than 6 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • Complete effacement indicates that the cervix has thinned out, which is a key indicator of active labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination: This indicates that the fetal head is still high in the pelvis and not yet engaged. It does not determine active labor.

 

Option B. Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes: This frequency and duration of contractions are not sufficient to determine active labor. Active labor typically involves regular, strong contractions lasting 45-60 seconds and occurring every 2-3 minutes.

 

Option D. Rupture of membranes: While rupture of membranes can occur during labor, it is not a definitive indicator of active labor. Cervical dilation and effacement are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active labor is determined by more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation with complete effacement, according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Ref: Page no 138, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of a painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Syphilis

 

Given scenario points out to a diagnosis of syphilis

 

ACQUIRED SYPHILIS:

 

Mode of acquisition - Sexual transmission & Blood transfusion

 

Stages are as follows –

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: In this condition both genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy are painful. It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, with an incubation period of 2-5 days.

 

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: It causes painful ulcers in the genital region and localized tender lymphadenopathy, caused by HSV 2 > 1.

 

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale (aka donovanosis): It is caused by the bacterium Calymmatobacter / Klebsiella granulomatis. There is NO pain in Ulcer & NO Lymphadenopathy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary syphilis (syphiLESS) is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a Painless genital ulcer and Painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, which are classic presentations of this sexually transmitted infection.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no: 28.8-29, 29.13-16

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 339, 341, 342

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 379-383

questions.text: A child is having fecal discharge from the umbilicus. What is the abnormality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Patent vitello-intestinal duct

 

The patent vitello-intestinal duct, also known as a patent omphalomesenteric duct, is an abnormality where the duct that normally connects the yolk sac to the midgut during fetal development fails to close. This duct connects the ileum to the future umbilicus, and if it remains completely patent, it can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, as seen in this case.

 

The persistence of the entire duct results in a direct communication between the ileum and the umbilicus, which can cause fecal matter to be discharged through the umbilicus. This condition is also referred to as an enterocutaneous fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalo-mesenteric cyst: This condition occurs when only a part of the vitello-intestinal duct remains patent in the middle, leading to a cystic swelling along the tract of the former duct. It does not cause fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Remnant urachus: The urachus is a remnant of the fetal connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. A patent urachus would result in urine discharge from the umbilicus, not fecal discharge.

 

Option D. Omphalocele:  Presents with abdominal wall defect with herniation of intestines covered by peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal discharge from the umbilicus in a child is indicative of a patent vitello-intestinal duct, which involves the persistence of the fetal duct connecting the ileum to the umbilicus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desflurane

 

  • Desflurane is a highly pungent gas, and its use for inhalational induction can lead to airway irritation, coughing, breath-holding, and even laryngospasm, especially in pediatric patients.
  • Therefore, desflurane is not typically used as an induction agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: Due to its pleasant odor and rapid onset, Halothane was historically a popular choice for inhalational induction in children. However, concerns regarding hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias have reduced its usage in modern practice.

 

Option B. Sevoflurane: Sevoflurane is one of the most commonly used agents for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its non-irritating nature and rapid kinetics.

 

Option D. Nitrous Oxide: Nitrous oxide is often used as an adjunct to other inhalational anesthetics for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and is generally well-tolerated by pediatric patients. It can be used for inhalational induction, especially in combination with more potent agents like sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane is not typically used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients due to its pungent nature, which can cause significant airway irritation and laryngospasm.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a recent type B aortic dissection presents with abdominal pain and lower limb ischemia with diminished femoral and popliteal pulses. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Repair the descending aorta

 

Option C:

 

New-onset abdominal pain and limb ischemia in a patient with type B aortic dissection indicate a complicated dissection, likely due to malperfusion of the mesenteric and lower extremity arteries. This requires urgent surgical or endovascular repair.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enalaprilat: Although used for blood pressure control, it doesn't address the underlying issue of malperfusion.

 

Option B. Increasing nitroprusside: May help with blood pressure control but doesn't solve the urgent need for revascularization.

 

Option D.  Switching to amlodipine: Not appropriate in an acute setting requiring immediate intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the signs of complicated type B aortic dissection (malperfusion syndromes) and the need for immediate surgical/endovascular repair.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefazolin

 

The drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery is Cefazolin, a first-generation cephalosporin. This class of antibiotics is preferred due to their efficacy against the most frequently encountered pathogenic organisms causing surgical site infections in cardiac surgeries.

 

  • Antimicrobial prophylaxis: Administered to cover the most frequently encountered pathogenic organisms causing surgical site infections.
  • Timing: The first dose should be given within 60 minutes before skin incision for an optimal duration of 24 hours but should not exceed 48 hours.
  • Special cases: In MRSA-positive cases, Vancomycin is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillin G: Not typically used for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery as it does not cover the range of organisms most commonly associated with surgical site infections in this context.

 

Option B. Erythromycin: Not the preferred choice for surgical prophylaxis in cardiac surgery due to its spectrum of activity and potential side effects.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: While it has a broad spectrum of activity, it is not the standard choice for preoperative prophylaxis in cardiac surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery is Cefazolin, administered within 60 minutes before incision to prevent surgical site infections.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E-FAST

 

Given the scenario described with the stab injury, bradycardia, hypotension, and clear lung fields on chest radiography, there's a concern for a potential cardiac injury and tamponade, and E-FAST would be the most rapid and effective tool to evaluate for these as well as other potential injuries.

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma. It is an ultrasound examination that is performed on trauma patients in the emergency department to identify any life-threatening conditions that need to be addressed immediately. The components of E-FAST include:

 

  1. Subxiphoid view: This assesses for pericardial effusion (fluid around the heart) which could indicate a cardiac tamponade.
  2. Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid (which could indicate internal bleeding) in Morrison's pouch (the space between the liver and the right kidney).
  3. Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid in the splenorenal recess (the space between the spleen and the left kidney).
  4. Suprapubic view: This assesses for free fluid in the pelvis.
  5. Anterior Chest view: This is performed bilaterally to assess for pneumothorax (air in the pleural space that can cause lung collapse) or hemothorax (blood in the pleural space).

 

The "extended" in E-FAST refers to additional views which can be added depending on the patient's condition and the clinician's suspicion of injury. These may include views of the thoracic spine and the lung bases to look for signs of additional injury.

 

 

E-FAST: Given the patient's presentation with hypotension, this would be the most appropriate initial step to rapidly identify a life-threatening condition in an unstable patient, like cardiac tamponade, which can cause bradycardia and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tube thoracostomy: Also known as a chest tube placement, it is used to treat pneumothorax or hemothorax by draining air or blood from the pleural space. However, in this patient, the chest radiography showed clear lung fields, suggesting that he does not have a significant hemothorax or pneumothorax.

 

Option C. CECT chest: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the chest can provide detailed images of the chest's anatomy and may identify injuries to the thoracic structures. However, in an acutely unstable trauma patient, a CT scan is not the best initial test due to the time it takes to perform and the need to transport the patient to the scanner.

 

Option D. CECT abdomen: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen can identify injuries to the abdominal organs. However it will be avoided in an unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST is a rapid ultrasound examination used in trauma patients to assess for life-threatening conditions such as cardiac tamponade, hemothorax, and pneumothorax. It is the most appropriate initial step for an unstable patient with a stab injury, bradycardia, and hypotension, given its ability to quickly provide critical information needed for immediate management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, who had visited multiple plastic surgeons requesting correction of "face deformity," was referred to a Psychiatrist. The patient insists that her face is deformed and needs surgery despite no evidence of deformity in the examination. The patient persists with her demand despite family members’ and doctors' reassurances. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SSRI

 

The patient described in the question is suffering from Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). BDD is a mental health condition characterized by an excessive preoccupation with an imagined defect in appearance, or if a minor physical anomaly is present, the person's concern is markedly excessive. Patients often have poor or absent insight, believing firmly in the existence of their perceived defects.

 

The standard treatment for BDD includes Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) (DOC) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Even when a patient's insight is at a delusional level, SSRIs remain the first-line pharmacological treatment, as they help reduce obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors associated with the disorder. In this case, SSRIs would be the best management option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behavioural therapy: While behavioral therapy might offer some benefits, the specific first-line treatment for BDD is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which targets the distorted beliefs about appearance directly. The term "Behavioral Therapy" is broad and less specific, making SSRIs a more targeted choice.

 

Option C. Atypical antipsychotics: These medications are not considered first-line treatment for BDD. They may be used as adjuncts in severe cases where delusional beliefs persist despite SSRIs, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Option D. Allow her for surgery: Surgery is not a recommended treatment for BDD as it does not address the underlying psychiatric condition and often worsens the patient's mental health state by reinforcing their preoccupation with appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), especially when insight is poor or absent, SSRIs are the drug of choice for management, often in combination with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Surgery is contraindicated as it does not address the core psychological issue.

questions.text: A patient on antidepressants presented to you with hypotension. An ECG was done, which showed wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IV NaHCO3

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, which includes hypotension, wide QRS complexes, and right axis deviation on the ECG. TCAs can block sodium channels in the heart, leading to QRS widening and the potential for serious arrhythmias. They also have anticholinergic effects, which can contribute to the clinical picture.

 

The first-line treatment for TCA overdose, especially in the presence of cardiac toxicity such as wide QRS complexes, is intravenous sodium bicarbonate (IV NaHCO3). Sodium bicarbonate works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to overcome the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs. It also increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which can help stabilize cardiac cell membranes and improve conduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antiarrhythmics: While antiarrhythmics might be considered in other cases of cardiac arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for TCA overdose. In fact, some antiarrhythmic drugs can worsen the condition by further blocking sodium channels or prolonging the QT interval.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used to treat high blood pressure and certain types of arrhythmias. However, it is not indicated for the treatment of TCA toxicity and can potentially exacerbate hypotension and cardiac conduction abnormalities.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant that can also be used for certain types of arrhythmias. However, it is not effective in treating the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs and is not recommended for managing TCA overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for tricyclic antidepressant overdose, especially when presenting with wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation, is intravenous sodium bicarbonate (IV NaHCO3).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.

 

Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Wei's syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver.

 

Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia ( aka Fagets sign) can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chikungunya: Typically presents with fever, severe joint pain, and rash, not prominently featuring jaundice or hepatic involvement.

 

Option C. Dengue hemorrhagic fever: While this can present with fever and potential liver involvement, the hallmark is severe bleeding and plasma leakage.

 

Option D. Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A: Generally presents with jaundice and neurological symptoms due to liver dysfunction but does not typically include calf pain or conjunctival suffusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of fever, jaundice, muscle pain, and conjunctival suffusion, especially if there is a history of exposure to potentially contaminated water. Recognizing these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 160/100 mmHg

 

  • The ISH (International society of HTN) 2020 guidelines were made to help decision making in low-middle income countries.
  • Presence of ASCVD risk factors, HMOD (HTN mediated organ damage) is an indication to start anti-HTN therapy.
  • Home BP recording helps in diagnosis of Masked HTN, rule out white-coat effect
  • ABPM provides 24-hour trend and fluctuations in BP.

 

 

Home BP > 135/85 mmHg = HTN

 

ABPM cutoffs:

 

  1. Mean Awake (daytime) average ≥ 135/85 mmHg
  2. 24h average ≥ 130/80 mmHg
  3. Mean Asleep(night) ≥ 120/70 mmHg

 

BP drops at night by (10-20%), morning surge – Steep increase, peaks in late afternoon.
 

Best observed in ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring):

 

  • Normal Dip: 10-20 % at night
  • Extreme Dip > 20%
  • Non-dippers < 10% (A/w Activation of RAAS)
  • Risers: BP raise

 

Note: Increase mortality risk among Non-Dippers and Risers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate pharmacological treatment for hypertension in patients without additional cardiovascular risk factors or organ damage should commence when blood pressure levels exceed 160/100 mmHg, according to the ISH 2020 guidelines. This approach helps to target treatment to those most likely to benefit from immediate intervention, balancing the benefits and risks of pharmacotherapy.

 

Reference: ISH2020, AHA2017 HTN guidelines

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRSA

 

Contact-based isolation precautions are specifically employed for managing patients who are infected with or are carriers of MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). MRSA is known for its ability to spread via direct contact with infected or colonized individuals, or indirectly through contact with contaminated surfaces and objects. This isolation strategy involves using personal protective equipment, such as gloves and gowns, when interacting with the patient, and applying rigorous hygiene practices to prevent the spread of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria: While also a communicable disease, it primarily requires droplet-based isolation due to its transmission through respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. Mumps: Similar to diphtheria, mumps is spread through respiratory droplets and thus requires droplet precautions.

 

Option D. Asthma: Not an infectious disease; it is a chronic respiratory condition that does not require transmission-based precautions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:

 

  • Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with colicky pain. Following type of crystals were found on urine examination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystinuria

 

The urine examination shows hexagonal crystals, which are characteristic of cystine crystals. These crystals are pathognomonic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder that affects the renal reabsorption of dibasic amino acids, including cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. Cystinuria leads to the formation of cystine stones in the kidneys, bladder, and ureters, often presenting with colicky pain due to stone obstruction.

 

Cystine crystals appear as flat, hexagonal plates, which is a distinctive feature that helps differentiate them from other types of crystals seen in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ADPKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): This condition involves the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney enlargement and dysfunction. It does not typically present with hexagonal crystals in the urine; the crystals seen are more commonly calcium oxalate.

 

Option B. Calcium oxalate stones: These stones are among the most common kidney stones and appear as envelope or dumbbell-shaped crystals, not hexagonal. They are usually related to hyperoxaluria and not cystinuria.

 

Option D. Glomerulonephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys, leading to symptoms like hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension. It does not present with specific crystals like the hexagonal cystine crystals seen in cystinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hexagonal cystine crystals in urine are characteristic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder affecting the renal absorption of certain amino acids, leading to recurrent cystine stone formation.

questions.text:
PQLI indicators include: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Literacy rate
  2. Infant mortality rate
  3. Life expectancy at birth
  4. Income per capita
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Only two of these

 

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to assess the quality of life in different countries. It focuses on three main indicators: health, education, and living standards. Specifically, these indicators include:

 

1. Literacy Rate (Education): This measures the education level within a population and is included in the PQLI.

 

2. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) (Living Standards): This measures the number of infants who die before reaching one year of age, reflecting living conditions and healthcare quality. It is included in the PQLI.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Life Expectancy at Birth: This is not included in the PQLI; instead, PQLI considers life expectancy at age one.

 

4. Income per Capita: This is not part of the PQLI; income measurements are used in the Human Development Index (HDI) but not in PQLI.

 

Thus, only the literacy rate and infant mortality rate are included in the PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PQLI measures the quality of life based on literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one, excluding income and life expectancy at birth.

 

Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:
