Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: The preferred test for evaluating the difference in means between two study groups, where one group functions as a control, is: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Unpaired t test

 

When comparing the means of two independent groups, where one group serves as a control, the appropriate statistical test to use is the unpaired t-test. This test is designed to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of the two independent groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: This test is used for categorical data to assess whether there is a significant association between two variables.

 

Option B. Z test: The Z test is typically used for large sample sizes to compare the means of two populations or to test proportions.

 

Option D. Paired T test: The paired t-test is used when comparing means from the same group at different times or under different conditions (e.g., before and after treatment).

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is un-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is non-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor
Drug A is un-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the drugs shown in graph A and graph B is correct. (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

 

To determine the correct answer, let's analyze the Lineweaver-Burk plots and the types of enzyme inhibition they represent:

 

For non-competitive inhibitors, the lines intersect at the x-axis. This type of inhibitor decreases VmaxVmax​ without affecting KmKm​.

 

Option A. Competitive Inhibition: On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibitors intersect with the no-inhibitor line at the y-axis. This is because competitive inhibitors increase the apparent KmKm​ (Michaelis constant) without affecting VmaxVmax​ (maximum velocity).

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors result in parallel lines on the Lineweaver-Burk plot. They decrease both VmaxVmax​ and KmKm​ proportionally. 

 

Given the descriptions of the graphs:

 

  • Graph A: The lines meet at the y-axis, indicating competitive inhibition.
  • Graph B: The lines start from the same point on the x-axis, indicating non-competitive inhibition.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

B. Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is characterized by development of morphologically similar lesions along the lines of trauma:  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isomorphic phenomenon

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

 

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Gottron's papule seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D: Meyerson phenomenon is a melanocytic nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon) as the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 123.2

questions.text: After using a hair dye a lady developed a skin reaction as shown in the image. Which of the following chemicals among given options is responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Para-Phenylenediamine

 

The history of hair dye use and above image points to a diagnosis of contact dermatitis due to an allergen called Para phenylenediamine.

 

Contact Dermatitis is of 2 types:

 

 

Diagnosis of Allergic CD – PATCH TEST

 

Examples of Allergic CD:

 

  1. Hair dye: PPD (para phenylenediamine)
  2. Metal: Nickel (most common)
  3. Topical antibiotic: Neomycin
  4. Cement: Potassium dichromate
  5. Bindi: PTBP (para tertiary butyl phenol)

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pollen:

 

  • Pollen is a common allergen that can cause allergic reactions in some individuals.
  • However, the use of hair dye does not typically involve exposure to pollen, so it is unlikely to be the cause of the skin reaction in this context.

 

Option B. Chromates:

 

  • Chromates, particularly hexavalent chromium compounds, can be found in some industrial processes and certain products.
  • While exposure to chromates can cause skin reactions in some cases, they are not commonly found in hair dyes, so they are less likely to be the cause here.

 

Option C. Balsam of Peru:

 

  • Balsam of Peru is a known allergen found in various cosmetics and fragrance products.
  • It can cause allergic contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
  • If the hair dye contains Balsam of Peru, it could be a potential allergen, but it is not as commonly associated with hair dye allergies as PPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is a common cause of allergic contact dermatitis (delayed hypersensitivity reaction) associated with hair dye use.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition: 89.73 128.15, 128.42, 128.60

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Histamine 

 

Histamine is involved in the mediation of inflammatory vascular events rather than fever.

 

Fever is defined by an increase in body temperature of 1° to 4°C. It is a prominent manifestation of the acute-phase response, particularly when associated with infection.

 

Pyrogens are substances that cause fever. They can be either exogenous or endogenous.

 

  • Endogenous progens include IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
  • Exogenous pyrogens are bacterial lipopolysaccharides that stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous progens (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Cytokines increase the activity of cyclooxygenases, which convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the hypothalamic vascular and perivascular cells. They stimulate the production of neurotransmitters in the hypothalamus, which raises the temperature setpoint. This is especially true of PGE2.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. IL-1, B. Prostaglandins and C. TNF: These are all endogenous pyrogens that directly contribute to the fever response by influencing the temperature regulation in the hypothalamus and stimulating the production of prostaglandins that raise the body’s temperature setpoint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is involved in mediating the local vascular effects of inflammation and not in the fever response, which is primarily driven by IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TLD badge

 

Explanation:

 

Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

 

 

  • Given to radiation personnel for its usage.
  • Personnel dosimeter.
  • Thermoluminescent
  • 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India]
  • Made up of CaSO4: Dysprosium [LiF can also be used]
  • Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collimators: Used in radiographic devices to narrow the beam of radiation to limit exposure and improve image quality, but not for monitoring radiation exposure.

 

Option C. Linear accelerator: A device primarily used in cancer treatment to deliver high-energy x-rays or electrons to the region of the patient's tumor. It is not a monitoring device.

 

Option D. Grid: Used in radiographic imaging to improve image contrast by absorbing scattered radiation, not for measuring radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A TLD badge is a critical tool for radiation safety, allowing for accurate monitoring and measurement of radiation exposure over time to ensure that radiation workers do not exceed safe exposure limits. This is crucial in maintaining occupational health standards in radiologically active environments.
